title: 111_hr5913
content:
The "Text a Tip Act of 2010" establishes a pilot program for texting crime tips. The Attorney General may grant funds to law enforcement agencies for an anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging. The funds can be used for program operation, promotion, and the Federal share should not exceed 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. The program requirements for the anonymous tip program using cell phone text messaging include funding from the Attorney General, with the Federal share not exceeding 75 percent of the program cost. Grant amounts should supplement non-Federal funds, not replace them. A texting tip program funded by the Attorney General must comply with specific requirements, including administering the program, stripping messages of identifying information, ensuring texts are untraceable, not replacing existing hotlines, training personnel to respond to tips, making the program compatible with mobile providers, and providing a code for follow-up information. The texting program funded by the Attorney General should be compatible with most mobile phone providers. It should include an unidentifiable code for tipsters to send follow-up information to law enforcement, allow for tip abortion, not impose additional fees on tipsters, and promote the program to encourage citizen participation, especially among youth. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS.

To request a grant under this Act, a State or local law enforcement agency must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information.

SEC. 5. REPORTS AND EVALUATIONS.

Recipients of grants must submit yearly reports on activities funded by the grant, and the Attorney General will report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the effectiveness of these activities. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

The term "texting tip program" refers to a program allowing citizens to anonymously text tips to law enforcement agencies to assist in criminal justice by removing identifying information from texts. "Texting" is defined as sending written messages from a mobile phone.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

The Attorney General is authorized to receive $5,000,000 annually from 2011 to 2016 to implement this Act.
